question:
The image above represents specimen A. Study it carefully and use it to answer Questions (a) - (d)

(a) List five advantages of using specimen A.

(b) State four maintenance activities that can be carried out daily on the specimen.

(c) State five maintenance practices that should be carried out periodically on the specimen.

(d) (i) What type of fuel is needed to operate specimen A ?
(ii) Does the specimen require a spark plug?
answer:
(a) Advantages of using specimen A include:

  • Tractor is used in drawing farm implements like ploughs, harrows, ridgers, planters,
  • It can also be a stationary power source for equipment like shellers, threshers, grinders etc.
  • It has hydraulic control system which aids the lifting of coupled implements.
  • It is used to carry farm inputs like chemicals, fertilizers, seeds etc. from one section of the farm to another.
  • It can also be used to carry harvested crops or other products from the farm to the market.
  • It can also be used to transport farm workers within the farm.
  • lt is used to clear bush, cultivate land, plant crops, weed and apply pesticides.
  • It can contribute to improved profitability by reducing labour costs, improving quality and quantity of produce 
  • Allow an increase in the size on the farm.

(b) Maintenance practices that can be carried out daily on specimen A include:

  • Keep the tractor clean by removing all trashes or mud from it at the start or at the end of operations.
  • Check water levels daily and top it when necessary.
  • Check oil level daily and top it when necessary.
  • Check tyre pressure daily before operation.
  • Inspect the tractor before starting every day.
  • Check electrolyte of battery every day and top when necessary 
  • Adhere strictly to manual or manufacturer's instructions.
  • Do not overload the tractor i.e operate at appropriate speed for farm operations.

(c) Maintenance practices that should be carried out periodically on specimen A include:

  • The tractor should be serviced at regular intervals.
  • Worn-out tyres Should be replaced.
  • Ensure that nuts, screws or shield are checked and tightened at regular intervals.
  • Replace worn-out parts of the tractors
  • Employ a competent and experienced tractor operator.

(d)(i)The type of fuel used by specimen A is diesel
(ii) No, ie. it does not require spark plug.

question:
(a) ldentify specimens B and C.

   

(b) Name the soil organisms which produce each of specimens B and C.

(c) State four beneficial effects of each of the organisms mentioned in (b) on agriculture.

(d) Why is it advisable to discourage multiplication of the organism which produces specimen C in a farm?

(e) Name two other soil organisms and their effects on soils
answer:
(a)) ldentification of specimens:

  • B - Worm Cast.
  • C - Ant hill.

(b) The soil organism which produces specimen B is earthworm while the one that produces specimen C is termite.

(c)(i) Four beneficial effects of organism producing specimen B on Agriculture are:

  • It helps in the decomposition of organic matter in the soil
  • It mixes soil mineral matter with organic matter
  • It improves the structure of the soil
  • It also improves the aeration of the soil

(ii) Four beneficial effects of organisms producing specimen C on Agriculture include:  

  • lt It helps in the decomposition of organic matter in the soil
  • They improve the soil structure
  • They improve soil aeration.
  • When they die, they add organic matter to the soil.

(d) lt is advisable to discourage the multiplication of the organism which produces specimen C in a farm for the following reasons;

  • They shift large amount of sub-soil to the surface thereby, forming ant hill which limits cultivable space
  • They destroy crop plants
  • They destroy wooden handles of farm tools.
  • They create wounds which serve entry point for disease pathogen on crop plants.

(e) Two other soil organisms are: (i) Millipede and (ii) Nematode 
(i) Effects of Millipedes on the soil

  • They aid decomposition of organic matter
  • They improve the structure of the soil
  • They allow easy percolation of water.
  • They improve soil aeration

(ii) Effects of Nematodes on the soil;

  • They help to improve the aeration of the soil.
  • They aid percolation of water
  • They improve the soil structure
  • Some are pests on major crops

question:
(a) ldentify specimens D, E, F, and G.

          

(b) What type of mouthparts is possessed by each of specimens D, E, F and G

(c) State one method of controlling specimen F.
answer:
(a) Identification of Specimen;

  • D is Grasshopper;
  • E is Aphid;
  • F is Cotton Stainer;
  • G is Weevils.

(b) Type of Mouth parts possessed by specimen;

  • D - Bitting and chewing
  • E - Piercing and Sucking
  • F - Piercing and Sucking
  • G - Boring

(c) Damages done by specimens D, E, F and G to crops

Specimen D;

  • Eats up the leaves and stems.
  • reduces the rate of photosynthesis.
  • reduces growth.
  • reduces yield.

Specimen E:

  • toxic saliva
  • transmits diseases.
  • reduces quality of boll.
  • leaf distortion. 

Specimen G:

  • bores holes into grains and eat them up
  • Reduces the quality of stored produce
  • Reduces grains to powder.

(d) Methods of controlling specimen F are:

  • Hand picking.
  • Spray with insecticides.

question:
Examine and study carefully specimen H and L.

   

(a) Name the part of the body of farm animals from which either specimen H or I can be found.

(b) Name the group of farm animals which possess each of specimens H and I

(c) A farmer has two types of livestock feed labelled X and Y. Feed X contains 60% milled maize cobs and 40% maize powder while feed Y contains 30% milled maize cobs and 70% maize powder. Which of the feeds, X or Y would a farmer feed the group of livestock possessing specimen H? Give four reasons for your answer.

(d) Draw a labelled diagram of specimen l to show its essential features.
answer:
(a) Specimen H is a piece of rumen which ís derived from the alimentary canal of ruminant animals e.g Cow while Specimen I is gizzard or alimentary canal of poultry bird up to gizzard. It is derived from the alimentary canal of a bird.

(b) Specimen H is possessed by ruminant animals like cattle, sheep and goat while specimen I is derived from non ruminant especially, poultry birds e.g. domestic fowl.

(c) Feed X contains 60% milled maize cobs and 40% maize powder while Feed Y contains 30% milled malze cobs and 70% maize powder. From the above feeds, a farmer would prefer to feed his livestock possessing specimen H ( rumen) with Feed X.

Reasons:

  • Livestock possessing specimen H has complex stomach structures which can easily digest feedX.
  • The digestion of feed X is aided by bacteria
  • Feed X is high in crude fibre and low in carbohydrate.
  • The livestock can ruminate on feed X.

(d)
